qas.question: What common artform is far more prestigious than mosaic?
Which culture adapted the use of mosaics for large ground coverings in their villas?
Most names of Roman mosaic workers are what nationality?
Often regular everyday craftsman were most likely what?
Carthage and Tunisia are in what general area?

context: Greek figural mosaics could have been copied or adapted <a0_0>paintings<a0_0/>, a far more prestigious artform, and the style was enthusiastically adopted by <a1_0>the Romans<a1_0/> so that large floor mosaics enriched the floors of Hellenistic villas and Roman dwellings from Britain to Dura-Europos. Most recorded names of Roman mosaic workers are <a2_0>Greek<a2_0/>, suggesting they dominated high quality work across the empire; no doubt most ordinary craftsmen were <a3_0>slaves<a3_0/>. Splendid mosaic floors are found in Roman villas across <a4_0>North Africa<a4_0/>, in places such as Carthage, and can still be seen in the extensive collection in Bardo Museum in Tunis, Tunisia.
